But, even when done with the best intentions, sending a child to a school affiliated to a church is a form of intellectual and emotional programming. It represents the opposite of liberal values.:Catholic schools are rated higher by inspectorsFor as long as it is possible to put a child through a denominational education, society is tacitly acknowledging the power of religion to define who people are. In an age when the state is increasingly non-religious in its decision-making, in order to maintain strict neutrality and equality, it makes no sense. When single-sex institutions are frowned upon as out-dated, when discrimination based on ethnicity, background or sexual orientation is considered abhorrent, it seems odd that this particular expression of dference is allowed to continue. Onlysectarianism were unheard of, rather than a persistent blight, would it ndash just about ndash be acceptable.Back in the real world, the existence of educational pigeon-holes like these means there is little hope of religious bigotry being eradicated. Those on either side of the school gates live in an environment that allows this shameful stain on our country to persist, and even flourish. Initiatives to raise awareness or to banish deep-rooted prejudices can never be wholly successful so long as the public statement of religious identity is allowed such a state-sanctioned .This is not to attack faith itself. What iniduals choose to believe, and the ways in which they introduce children to their religion or creed at home, is their business. Nor should schools cease to teach pupils about world religions, or to help them understand the huge cultural influence that Christianity, both Catholic and Protestant, has exerted on countless aspects of our lives, for good and ill.Complete integration, however, should be the goal. The building blocks of society must mirror the kind of world we want future generations to inherit. No matter how you look at it, denominational schools have become an anomaly. If sectarianism is to become a thing of the past, then so should they.

title: andrew-mckie-lib-dems-aren-39-t-liberal---ruthless-adaptors
story: I wonder whether she could bring herself to forgive a politician who stood on a manesto that promised a referendum on wide reform of the EU and joining the Euro, then on one that promised a straight In Out referendum on the EU with a guarantee to implement the result, then on one that promised to introduce a soft Brexit,that were the verdict after a second referendum that would offer remain as an option, then advocated a second referendum with a choice between no deal and remain, and later decided the best bet was a second referendum, to be ignored unless its answer was in favour of remaining in the EU, before get round to ldquoSod democracy letrsquos just cancel the whole thing without any voting at all. But since that politician is her, between  and now, I imagine she can.Even so, her partyrsquos current position may, in political terms, be their best bet since, despite the previous range of opinion in both parties, the Conservatives under Boris Johnson are the party of Brexit come hell or high water while Labour under Jeremy Corbyn have become, well, frankly, anyonersquos guess.Indeed, itrsquos mystying that the Lib Dems have not hoovered up more of the remain vote which was, after all,  per cent of the result. Yet polling has them at about  per cent . Being the Stop Brexit Party may be neither liberal nor democratic and, despite the impression given by Holyrood, Westminster, social and mainstream media, may even still be a minority view, but itrsquos certainly the one that ought to maximise the Lib Dem vote.The principal argument against it is that it wonrsquot happen, or as Niall Hodson, a brave dissenting delegate at the party conference, put it, lead to the Lib Dems ldquopromising something and doing something .The reason is that there is no prospect that the party will be the largest one at the next election, and Ms Swinson has already ruled out a coalition with either the Tories or Labour ndash something that this particular policy would, in any case, make extremely dficult.Itrsquos also an interesting inversion of the partyrsquos position in relation to the SNP, which criticised the Lib Dems for arguing against a second independence referendum, eventhe Nationalists geta majority of Scottish seats.Interesting because it seems reasonable to claim that, were the Lib Dems to win a majority of UK seats, that would look like a mandate to halt Brexit, while itrsquos highly contentious to claim that an SNP majority at either Holyrood or in Scottish Westminster seats automatically indicates a preference for independence, or even a second go at a referendum. Thatrsquos because the SNP are Scotlandrsquos Lib Dems.Of course, both parties have their true believers, who wholeheartedly support their respective policies. You can tell thatrsquos true, because they do so even when the policies are the polar opposite of what they were a decade ago. But both also attract support from people who canrsquot bring themselves to vote Conservative or Labour at any given moment. Particularly because lots of people who formerly supported one of the two largest parties wonrsquot, in any circumstances, vote for the other. Naturally, that goes double for defecting MPs, who almost all, Tory or Labour, discover theyrsquove secretly been Liberal Democrats all along.But the electoral arithmetic translates the SNP voteinto majorities and real power. It doesnrsquot do the same for the Lib Dems ndash one reason why they are, reasonably enough, obsessed by the mechanics of the electoral system ndash except in by-elections, where they are famously dirty and successful campaigners.In Scotland, the anti-Brexitvote is SNP, unless the other Union is an even greater priority. But itrsquos not clear where the Lib Dems can make major gains in England and Wales, even though there should, one would think, be loads of people bursting to vote for them. Many key swing seats are straight Tory Labour marginals, while the traditional Lib Dem heartland of the South West of England is, oddly enough, a Leave-voting area.Voters who want above all to stop Brexit will, and indeed probably should, vote Lib Dem. In England, it may be their only option. If they believe in other Lib Dem policies, or at least prefer them to Tory and Labour ones, thatrsquos a bonus. ButBrexit is halted or reversed, it wonrsquot be by a Lib Dem government, because there isnrsquot going to be one.

title: papers-let-bbc-crew-film-herald-newsroom
story: ldquoItrsquos great publicity. ldquoWorked brilliantly for us.ldquoYour readers will love the insight.When viewers, media commentators, family and friends tune in tonight, I would be surprisedtheir reactions donrsquot match those already offered pre-screening.After all, it is not every day you open up your newsroom to a rival media organisation and put your trust in them. And trust, in this world of fake news, is at the heart of The Herald brand and one of the main reasons we chose to do this.You trust us to deliver the news impartially, with honesty and integrity. The documentary is a quality production, like all our titles, and provides unique analysis, insight and opinionndash the cornerstones of The Heraldrsquos daily coverage.So, just as we strive to deliver in print and online on a daily basis, the TV show strips bare the gloss and spin and reveals the realities of the challenges we face.: Spotlight falls on Herald in new documentaryUnderpinning all this is our passionate, professional and dedicated team doing a superb job, in often dficult circumstances, to deliver quality coverage across news, politics, business, sport andthe arts.Welcome to The Herald, warts and all.TV fame and stardom beckonsThe media world was abuzz withchat about the imminent launch of two new Sunday titles, The Herald on Sunday and Sunday National when Maurice Smith of TVI Vision got in touch seeking to produce a documentary about the newspaper industry and The Heraldin particular. The timing could not have been better.We were days away from implementing a strategic decision to extend both The Herald and sister title The National across seven days. For The Herald brand, there had been confusion in the market place, including online, over an apolitical editorial stance Monday to Saturday and a left-wing, independence supporting Sunday Herald.The National championed an independent Scotland and catered for a market committed to that cause, but did not have a Sunday offering. Readers turned instead to The Sunday Herald but many Monday to Saturday Herald readers were alienated by The Sunday Heraldrsquos political stance. That impacted on sales and our online audiences.The solution was to rebrand The Sunday Herald and launch a Sunday National to cater for an independence-supporting audience seven days, and to produce a Herald on Sunday fully aligned with the political stance and values of Monday to Saturdayrsquos Herald.A unique marketing opportunity beckoned.A Bafta winner I had a positive response to allowing the cameras in when, as Editor of The Sunday Post, we celebrated its centenary, and the experience of others in the spotlight, such as Glasgow Central Station and Edinburgh Airport, shows that providing the public with a unique insight helps provide a welcome understanding of our roles, responsibilities and challenges.However, it was important for our brands, The Herald, Evening Times and The National, to ensure that the production company had a track record of excellent work.Documentary producer director Sarah Howitt made the first series of ldquoScotlandrsquos Superhospital ndash following the move to the new hospital and more recently The Force: The Story of Scotlandrsquos police, which was nominated for a Scottish Bafta for Best Factual Series and for a Royal Television Society award for the same.Maurice and Sarah first worked together in  on a documentary entitled The Bridge: Fty Years Across The Forth, which won the Bafta Scotland best single documentary in . They also collaborated on The Town That Thread Built and Six Weeks To Save The World.Importantly, it was commissioned for the BBC, where context and impartiality are regarded as critical. Again, in the same way, we ask our public to trust our journalists to be fair and balanced, there is an expectation of the same from the BBC.So in rolled the camerashellip but for much longer than expected. More of that later.: Jeane Freeman announces public inquiry into building flaws at QEUH and Edinburgh Sick KidsTrust, credibility andfake newsSadly, despite our remarkable -year history, The Herald is not immune from the same criticism levelled at all mediandashthat we produce fake news, suppress and distort the truth. We are the worldrsquos longest-running national newspaper, but that counts for little amongst the online trolls who only want an echo chamber fort views.Our critics often use it as to beat us with. What better opportunity to show our integrity, balance, fairness and lack of bias.In addition, like most journalists, nothing irritates me more than seeing our profession and industry portrayed in dramas, soap and films as insensitive, intrusive and reckless with the truth.I am sure when you sit down to enjoy the shows you will see professional, dedicated and caring staff interested only in their audiences quality journalism.The Herald is staunchly apolitical. Importantly, audiences will see how wrong accusations of any political bias are. We represent all views and have brilliant columnists ndash given complete freedom to express their opinions.Insight and understandingThe news industry is challenged by growing digital consumption and declining print readership. We reach record overall audiences and are getting ever closer to the point where digital revenues and growing commercial partnerships exceed the more traditional revenue s in print. As we make that seismic transition, we need to manage our costs to allow us to continue to invest in the multi-media offering that will protect our long-term futureQuality journalism, be it in print or online, is expensive. Balancing that equation means streamlining processes, increasing efficiencies, structural changes and dficult conversations. The cameras were there to capture it all ndash painful though it was.Almost every industry has its own challenges and as journalists, we report without fear or favour. For viewers to have trust in us and our brand to have credibility it was important to be open and honest. Our readers will have a better insight and understanding of the complexities and dficulties of delivering quality content across many s and see that our commitment remains as strong as ever.Brexit madnessThe documentary features our comprehensive coverage of Brexit, free of any partisan agenda, and delivered for a Scottish audience. It shows our specialist teams at Holyrood and Westminster providing insight and analysis amid the chaos and confusion.It was to be a three-month period where we had to mind our language as the cameras covered the build-up to the UKrsquos exit from the EU. Delay after delay, deals, no deals and daily disarray pushed the timescale back to March . A full six months and not a stylist, make-up artist or personal trainer in sight!Meet the castThe media industry is full of characters and larger than le personalities. They are passionate, pedantic, argumentative and opinionated. But everyone is proud to work for The Herald The Herald on Sunday and our sister titles, the Evening Times and The National Sunday National.They come to le through the lenses that followed them for what seemed an eternity and light up the screen in the same way they do our pages on a daily basis. Irsquom proud of every one of them and hope you will welcome the opportunity tonight to see the people who make The Herald a compelling read in print and online.l Tomorrow: How internet giants Google and Facebook are destroying the media industry.The Papers, BBC, at pm tonight.

title: virgin-offer-new-flights-scotland-third-runway-opens
story: The airline said the transformation of its route network depends on how many additional take-of and landing slots it obtains when the UKrsquos busiest airport is expanded.Chief executive Shai Weiss claimed the west London hub has been dominated by British Airwaysrsquo parent company IAG ldquofor far too long.Twelve of the  new destinations Virgin Atlantic plans to serve from Heathrow are in the UK or Channel Islands.Thee others areBelfast City, Exeter, Guernsey, Liverpool, Jersey, Manchester, Newcastle and Newquay.Catriona Stewart:Heathrow drone strikes: How do we halt the desire to fly Virgin Atlanticrsquos planned  new long-haul routes include airports in North and South America, Asia and Africa.A recent report commissioned by the airline found that IAG holds % of Heathrow slots.Virgin Atlantic intends to compete on  routes where it says IAG has a monopoly.The rules governing the allocation of new airport slots are currently being reviewed by the Department for Transport.Virgin Atlantic axed its domestic airline, Little Red, in September  and blamed a scarcity of available slots at Heathrow as one of the reasons for its failure.IAG chief executive Willie Walsh told an airport conference in November  that there is ldquozero chance the airline group will restore flights to UK airports such as Liverpool and Newquay, evenmore slots become available.ldquoWersquoll go where therersquos demand, he added.Read more:Drivers warned over kiss and fly airport drop off feesMr Weiss said: ldquoNever has the need for effective competition and choice at Heathrow Airport been more evident than during this summer of disruption, which has brought misery for tens thousands of travellers. Britain, and those who travel to it, deserve better than this.ldquoAir passengers need a choice and Virgin Atlantic is ready to deliver when Heathrow expands.ldquoHeathrow has been dominated by one airline group for far too long.ldquoThe third runway is a once-in-a-letime opportunity to change the status quo and create a second flag carrier.ldquoThis would lower fares and give real choice to passengers, as well giving Britain a real opportunity to boost its trade and investment links around the world.ldquoChanging the way take-off and landing slots are allocated for this unique and vital increase in capacity at the nationrsquos hub airport will create the right conditions for competition and innovation to thrive.A group of councils, residents, environmental charities and London Mayor Sadiq Khan lost a High Court challenge against the Governmentrsquos decision to approve the plans for the third runway in May. But in July they were given the go-ahead to challenge the ruling.Construction could begin in  and the new runway could be opened by .

title: scotlands-future-not-settled-five-years-independence-vote
story: While a majority of Scots voted to keep the country in the UK in , support for the SNP soared in the aftermath, with party membership rising to more than ,.Just eight months after the vote on independence, the SNP enjoyed a landslide victory in the Westminster election, winning  of the  seats up for grabs in Scotland.It reduced Labour, the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats to just one MP each north of the border.:Iain Macwhirter: Five years on, a velvet orce could now be the way aheadScottish Labourrsquos support in particular plummeted after campaigning with the Tories in the cross-party Better Together campaign in the run-up to the referendum.In the  Holyrood election, which took place just a few weeks before the UK-wide referendum on Britainrsquos European Union membership, the SNP manesto said a fresh ballot should be heldthere was a ldquomaterial change in circumstances from .The SNP won the election, though Nicola Sturgeon lost the overall majority her predecessor Alex Salmond had secured at Holyrood in .When the UK voted for Brexit in June  ndash and % of Scots said they wanted to stay part of the EU ndash the SNP insisted it had a mandate for another vote.Indeed, the day after the Brexit referendum, Ms Sturgeon said a second independence vote was ldquohighly likely.In March , MSPs backed her demands for discussions with Westminster over a fresh ballot ndash although then-prime minister Theresa May said it was ldquonot the time for another referendum.With the prospect of a no-deal Brexit now looming, and with Boris Johnson having succeeded Mrs May in Downing Street, Ms Sturgeon is stepping up her calls.In May, the First Minister suggested ldquotowards the latter half of next year would the the ldquoright time for the question of independence to be put to Scots again.:Petition launched to require two-thirds majority for independenceDays later, the Scottish Government published legislation that could pave the way for a fresh vote on Scottish independence, with Ms Sturgeon saying then it would be ldquodemocratic outrageWestminster were to block this.In July, she said Mr Johnson becoming PM meant it was ldquomore important than ever for the Scottish Government to plan for such a vote.An opinion poll from Lord Ashcroft and Holyrood magazine in August put support for independence at %, when donrsquot knows were excluded, with % for the UK.Elections expert Professor Sir John Curtice said at the time this was ldquoconsistent with the claim that in recent weeks there has been a small but potentially signicant swing in favour of Yes.He said the poll had found there was ldquoas much as a -point lead for Yes among Remain voters.The professor added the new PM was ldquodeeply unpopular among those who voted Remain.

title: scotlands-economy-brink-recession
story: Official figures found Scottish GDP fell by . per cent in the second quarter of the year.Two consecutive quarters of negative growth is the technical definition of a recession.SNP Finance Secretary Derek Mackay blamed Brexit.The UK economy shrank by .% over the same period.Over the year to June, Scottish GDP grew by just .% compared to .% for the UK.A key factor in the latest figures was a see-sawing of business activity on either side of the original Brexit deadline of March .In the quarter ahead of the date, many firms stockpiled goods in case of no-deal, with the increased economic activity lting GDP.After the deadline was extended, that process went into reverse as firms ran down their stocks and economic activity sagged."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Countdown to Brexit:  days until Britain leaves the EU","description": "Countdown to Brexit:  days until Britain leaves the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media sfpYlAw poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests sfpYlAw.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": A fallback in food and draink and pharmaceutical industries, which helped drive the .% rise in Scottish GDP in the first quarter, accounted for the whole .% fall in the second.Mr Mackay said: ldquoGiven the repeated warnings from business organisations and the contraction across the UK in the same quarter, it is unsurprising but deeply frustrating that we are now seeing the Brexit impact on the Scottish economy."The responsibility for this contraction lies entirely with the UK Government.ldquoWe are already taking steps to protect jobs and our economy from Brexit but not every impact can be mitigated. We will continue to stand firm against efforts to take us out of the EU against our will.On a visit to the Codebase technolgy incubator in Edinburgh, Mr Mackay added:ldquoIt is worrying news, but I do believe it is the consequence of the Brexit threat.Askedhe was concerned about the prospect of a recession, he said: ldquoYes, I am."All the economic consensus is, and this is a further warning shot, that this contraction for Quarter  is a concern and the economic consensus is thattherersquos any form of Brexit there will be a negative economic impact."Butthere is a no-deal Brexit, then I feel itrsquos now a certainty there will be a recession.Asked about independence causing even more uncertainty, he said: ldquoWersquove been able to show how independence can help us grow our economy, have a more prosperous and fairer society. Wersquove shown the dference independence would make.ldquoIt would give us the abilities that small independent countries around the world have to react to events and grow their economies, and be more agile and resilient.Scottish Secretary Alister Jack said: ldquoldquoI am concerned the Scottish economy has shrunk over the last quarter and continues to lag behind UK-wide figures.ldquoComing on the back of disappointing unemployment figures, more needs to be done to boost our economy and close the gap.ldquoWe will continue to work with the Scottish Government to boost the Scottish economy and create jobs. To date, the UK Government has committed pound.bn in city and growth deals and we will seize all of the opportunities that will arise once we leave the EU.ldquoI urge the Scottish Government to use the considerable powers at their disposal to improve the Scottish economy rather than holding it back with threats of a second independence referendum and the decision to make Scotland the most highly taxed part of the UK.Professor Graeme Roy from the Fraser of Allander Institute said: ldquoThe data today confirm that, like the UK as a whole, the Scottish economy contracted in the second quarter of .ldquoEconomic activity has proven particularly volatile this year as Brexit uncertainty has affected the pattern of business activity.ldquoIn the first three months of the year we saw activity boosted by firms stockpiling supplies in the event that the UK exited the EU at the end of March.ldquoWhen this did not come to pass, and the next deadline was pushed to October , we saw firms run down these stockpiles leading to lower levels of activity.ldquoThis was most clearly evident in activity in the production sectors of the economy. We saw this in the UK wide data, and we see this in the data released this morning for Scotland.ldquoIn manufacturing for example, output grew by +.% in Q, only to be followed by a contraction of -.% in Q.ldquoThe early evidence suggests that activity in the UK economy has picked up in recent months. Whilst fragile, this suggests that a technical recession ndash i.e. two consecutive quarters of falling output ndash appears unlikely.ldquoOf course, all this could changethe Brexit process was to further unravel.ldquoAs always, we urge people to focus on longer term growth rather than inidual quarter to quarter fluctuations. Over the last year growth was +.%, far from Scotlandrsquos long-term average growth rate, and lagging the UK over the same period where growth was +.%.Scottish LibDem leader Willie Rennie said: ldquoThe impact of Brexit is hitting investment, jobs and living standards, and the main phase hasnrsquot even happened yet. That is why the Lib Dems are right to offer people a way to make it stop, with our revoke policy.Economist John McLaren of Scottish Trends added: ldquoLike the UK, Scotlandrsquos economy has performed poorly in the second quarter of . This was largely down to a reversal of the, stockpiling related, fast growth seen in Manufacturing in Q.ldquoLooking at Scotlandrsquos performance over a longer timeframe and across sectors suggests that the Manufacturing sector has performed relatively well over the past decade. However, Distribution services and Business services have shown a worrying underperformance over the past  to  years.ldquoIn addition, the Health and Social Work sector, despite signicant boosts to the NHS budget, has seen falling outputsince , in contrast to most other parts of the UK. Such a contraction highlights concerns over falling Scottish productivity in this sector.Scottish Labour MP Ian Murray, on behalf of the Best for Britain campaign, said: ldquoConstitutional upheaval is causing economic turmoil in Scotland and across the UK."If we crash out of the EU without a deal then the economic damage will be considerably more severe."These figures relate to peoples livelihoods - jobs and incomes. Thats what Boris Johnson is gambling with."The threat to the Union is also causing unnecessary economic uncertainty."We need a final say on Brexit with the chance to grow the Scottish and British economies and the opportunity for the UK to remain in the EU."Andrew McRae, of the Federation of Small Businesses, said the figures were ldquodishearteningunsurprising.He said: ldquoAcross the country, firms are either pouring resources into Brexit planning or postponing critical decisions until our political leaders get their act together. That means that theyrsquore not using every tool at their disposal to create jobs and drive growth.ldquoThe small business priority is to avoid a no-deal, no-transition Brexit in just a few short weeks. Where possible, every business leader needs to take action to mitigate the risk of this chaotic outcome.ldquoBut therersquos no way such a scenario wouldnrsquot squeeze many operators. It must be avoided.ldquoNorth of the border, Holyrood decision-makers need to take note of the storm clouds on the horizon. The upcoming Scottish Government budget must focus on providing much needed stability and at every turn Ministers need to think twice about putting additional burdens on local firms.

title: meet-cast-bbcs-papers
story: :The Papers: Why we let a BBC crew film The Herald newsroomDonald Martin -Editor-in-chiefMy role is editor-in-chief and editor of the Herald, Herald on Sunday and the Evening Times ndash but that extended remit probably says more about being a cheaper option thanmy ability!I have been an editor now for almost  years at ious titles across the UK and it is a unique privilege, particularly editinga national quality newspaper like The Herald and your home cityrsquos evening title the Evening Times. I was brought up on both and have always had a great deal of affection for them.As an editor you are at the heart of major events, overseeing a quite brilliant team of journalists seeking to provide an insatiable audience with the content they want and can trust.Yes, it is hard at times, and my job now, like all senior editorial executives in this industry, often involves dficult conversations and decisions, but itrsquos still a thrill.Irsquove witnessed tremendous change during my  years in newspapers ndash indeed it is the one constant ndash and have never failed to be surprised by the resilience of hacks, coping with new technologies and resultant streamlining and restructures. We are continually adapting to changing demands and increasing competition but we are still here reaching record audiences.Andy Clark-Assistant Editor, Herald on SundayIrsquove been in journalism for more than  years and, honestly,I canrsquot imagine doing anything . Currently, Irsquom in charge of The Heraldrsquos Sunday edition, bringing together all aspects of the paper, which can be fun with the tiny team at my disposal.Itrsquos a frustrating, draining, tiring, stressful job. It can keep you up at night and ruin your holidays.:BBCs The Papers: Behind the scenes at The HeraldBut itrsquos also the most rewarding, creative, exciting thing. When a big story breaks, or when you cover an issue so well the country sits up and takes notice, itrsquos the best feeling in the world. I also love the people hellip the team spirit, the banter, the swearing .And after all this time, wouldI do it all again, knowing whatI do now  Ask me five times throughout the week and Irsquoll give you five dferent answers.Marianne Taylor -Features Writer and ColumnistI wear a few dferent hats atThe Herald ndash literary editor, columnist, features writerndash which reflects the fact you need to be flexible in this game, able to turn your hand to dferent tasks. Especially when, like me, yoursquore a freelancer.But iety is undoubtedly one of the best things about this job, not least because it has given me the chance to do so many dferent things over the last  years, including living and working in London and Berlin . Intellectually, it can be challenging, but the other side of that coin is fulfilment.I canrsquot lie ndash I love being a journalist. I genuinely canrsquot think of anything  Irsquod rather do. Itrsquos not an easy ride ndash the demands and deadlinesare often ridiculous and overwhelming ndash and I could earn more money outside of newspapers. But the buzz of this job remains real and addictive. It sucks you in, and the adrenaline, banter and camaraderie keep you going.Will I get another  yearsout of this sometimes brutal industry  I canrsquot tell you how much I hope so.John-Paul Holden - Deputy News EditorI tookon this role atThe Herald in April last year.I manage the night newsdesk, meaning I have responsibility for ensuring the paper goes off to the printers by the deadline and in good shape.I sometimes call it the graveyard sht. At the sharp end, with only the night team left, the newsroom can bevery quiet. Dinner is usually consumed in front of a computer screen and I gave up on a weekday social le a long time ago. But when a late story breaks, things get intense, frantic and exciting in theblink of an eye.Keeping coolis a must ... but I donrsquot always succeed.Straddling the demands of print and digital coverage is perhaps the biggest challenge of all.Times are undoubtedly tough. That said, bringing readers the news, particularly as the Brexit fiasco deepens, still feels like an immense privilege.Catriona Stewart - Senior Reporter and ColumnistTo say that every day is dferent would be a vast understatement.I joined the Evening Times  years ago as a general news reporter. Since then my remit has widened and now I have responsibility for covering the south side of Glasgow, education, crime, courts and investigations. As a senior reporter, I also act on the news deskour news editor is off.In addition, I write three columns a week: one for the Evening Times and two for The Herald. Juggling this can mean writing a column while at a crime scene or sitting on a grass verge at the side of the M. Itrsquos not uncommon to still be in the office late.With such a wide range of responsibilities, therersquos a constant sense of trying your best but never doing your best.This yearrsquos highlight has to be travelling to Sierra Leone to write about womenrsquos rights, a trip I did in my own time but a chance I wouldnrsquot have had without my link to the Evening Times. A social le falls by the wayside but would I change it I would not.Mark Eadie - Assistant EditorYes, thatrsquos me in the trailer of The Papers looking typically stressed and holding my head in my hands. As one crisis is solved another will always appear. I exaggerate a little, of course, but by its very nature ldquonews is unpredictable, meaning best-laid plans often crumble in an instant.As head of The Heraldrsquos production itrsquos my job to make sure all the elements ndash words, pictures and graphics ndash come together on the page in as presentable and sellable form as possible.Irsquove been at The Herald for five years, having previously cut my teeth at our arch-rivals in Edinburgh for  years. On bad days, working in a newspaper can feel like yoursquore slogging away on the production line ofa sausage factory for words,but on good daysyou reallydo feel as though your contribution, however small, has made a dference.Switching off after work is the biggest challenge. As Irsquom driving home in the wee small hours, ldquothe fear can often grip you ndash have I misspelt a word on the splash headline, are the puzzles correct  It can play havoc with your nervous system. In fact, hang on, Irsquod better check one last time.Kirsty Anderson - PhotographerlsquoOh, I was expecting a manrsquo is a less common greeting now than it was back when I started out nearly  years ago.As a photographer, Irsquove seen a massive change in technology and workload demands butitrsquos been hugely enjoyable, le-changing and taken me around the world. Irsquove also got to know the amazing iniduals I can call my colleagues and friends. The camaraderie is one of the things that has kept me going through rough times.Irsquove worked with some of the best, funniest and talented of journalists.Another of the great privileges of being a photographer is being invited into peoplersquos lives and represent their stories.From potholes to politicians therersquos never a moment the same as the last and, fingers crossed, there will be many more.

title: loyalist-group-march-past-scottish-independence-rally-weekend
story: The Independent Loyal Orange Order, who are a separate and much smaller institution from the Grand Orange Lodge ofScotland, expect  members to march between Blythswood Square and Abernethy St late on Saturday morning.As the group pass George Square, a crowd of thousands of pro-Independence supporters are expected to gather in the same area for a rally marking the anniversary of the  referendum.:Nicola Sturgeon lsquofighting for European futurersquo on visit to BerlinIn previous weeks flashpoints at parades across the city have seen violent incidents involving marchers, police and protestors.This led to a decision by Glasgow City Council to place a ban on six parades through the city taking place last weekend.Despite unionists and secessionists likely to be in the same area on Saturday morning, organisers from both groups have said they expect no trouble or flare-ups, with last years events by the same groups passing without incident.A spokesman for the Independent Loyal Orange Institutionsaid: "As this is an ILOI parade it will be well marshalled and we would expect it to take place in the usual non-provocative manner all our parades adhere to."It must be remembered that this is a parade by the independent order who have never had any problems with their parades. I cant see how there will be any issues. The lodge will just be standing up for its own culture."The councils draconian views shouldnt take away from our freedom of expression we fought for."If we were instructed not to march we would not be in a financial position to challenge the decision, but we would be bitterly disappointed."Hope Over Fear have said previous years have seen some shouting between the ILOI and pro-Independence supporters, but that stewards, working with Police Scotland, have avoided any trouble. So far, they say they have received no intel about threats from cops, with Police Scotland telling the Evening Times there was "nothing to report at this stage".Saturdays event will feature prominent pro-Independence politicians, but is not a march and as such is not considered by the councils public processions committee.:Rosemary Goring: If we want to end sectarianism, we must abolish Catholic schoolsHowever, organisers have spoken out about last weeks march ban, saying the recent violence showed a "sad state of affairs" but claiming the decision to prohibit was "not the way" to tackle the ide.A council spokesman said: ldquoThe route and timing of any procession are obviously among the key considerations we discuss with police and organisers ndash and that would naturally include taking into account other events taking place nearby.Meanwhile, the Grand Orange Lodge of Scotland have said they held a "constructive meeting" with the council and police officials following last weekends ban.Grand Master Jim McHarg wrote on the lodges website that progress was made towards a "hopeful resolution", with an agreement to a further meeting.

title: salmond-says-support-yes-60-per-cent-now
story: On the fth anniversary of the  referendum, the former First Minister tweeted a series of comments about what might have beenhe had been able to read the future.He said thathe had known five years ago that Boris Johnson and Brexit were coming, he would have delayed the independence referendum to help sht voter opinion.:Poll: Support for EU and holding a new Indyref risesWith hours of Scotland voting % for No, Mr Salmond announced his resignation and Nicola Sturgeon became First Minister two months later.Despite the upheaval over Brexit, most polls show support for independence has risen only slightly in the last five years, as previously No supporting Remain voters moe to Yes.Ms Sturgeon has faced growing dissent within the Yes movement in recent months for failing to capitalise on the current turmoil at Westminster.If I had but known  years ago that @BorisJohnson would become Prime Minister and Britain would be poised on the brink of a hard #Brexit then I would have delayed the Scottish referendum and now looked forward to a % plus Yes vote... [ ]#Independence pic BQsdZFYeMr Salmond wrote: "If I had but known  years ago that BorisJohnson would become Prime Minister and Britain would be poised on the brink of a hard #Brexit then I would have delayed the Scottish referendum and now looked forward to a % plus Yes vote."In reality, it is probably the case that Scotland had to experience the fundamental sht of opinion in our first referendum before acting decisively to seize the day next time around."Therefore on this fth anniversary, we should focus not on what might have been but on the opportunity still to come.":Readers react to petition requiring two-thirds majority for Scottish independence referendumPamela Nash, chief executive of the anti-independence Scotland in Union group, said:"Alex Salmondrsquos comments show there is no positive case for independence. He wants to rely on chaos and ision in society."His plan to break up the worldrsquos most successful union was rejected five years ago and is today opposed by even more Scots."He misled voters in  with bogus claims such as a threat to our NHS and neglected public services while focussing on iding our communities, so a period of silence from him would be welcome."Last December, Mr Salmond questioned Ms Sturgeonrsquos resolve to hold Indyref, suggesting the SNP was ldquounsure as to when, or even whither, to launch their Caledonian leboat.Ms Sturgeon subsequently announced plans to hold Indyref in the latter half of , but the UK Government has so far refused to grant Holyrood the powers required for a new vote.Ms Sturgeon is spending the fth anniversary of the referendum in Berlin.

title: opinion-matrix-moderation-short-supply
story: One common theme is a plea for moderation.The MailSome might expect Sarah Vine, we of Michael Gove, to hit back after former Prime Minister David Cameron described his ex-colleague as a lsquofoam-flecked Faragistrsquo in his memoirs. But the outspoken Mail columnist appears to have adopted the Michelle Obama doctrine: lsquowhen they go low we go highrsquo.A y piece titled lsquorequiem for a friendshiprsquo waxes lyrical about the two Toriesrsquo wives sharing the school run, joint family holidays and mutual experiences. ldquoSitting by the roaring fire in the Great Hall [at Chequers], bilious Elizabethans and their bug-eyed mistresses staring down unblinkingly at us from the walks, our children engaged in a riotous game of Capture the Flag, Dave producing an endless supply of White Ladies , captures the tone.There is more than a touch of lsquothe lady doth protest too muchrsquo about her conclusions, though: ldquodespite all that has been said and done [that] is how I will always remember Dave and Samantha. As dear friends who were there at key moments of my le.The ScotsmanIn the same paper Tory MSP Murdo Fraser makes a more direct plea for moderation. Claiming Christianity as the source of many ideas about equality and human rights, he bemoans the state of the body politic. ldquoIn our febrile debates around Brexit we see something of the spirit of : a digging of trenches, a placing of blame and a refusal to find common ground, he writes. Words such as traitor and collaborator are used by those more interested in conflict. ldquoWe need a new spirit of moderation of generosity and of putting the national interest and unity before narrow political considerations, because the alternative is yet more bitterness and ision.The Even bookshops are losing the plot according to Melanie McDonagh, who is agitated to learn some are refusing to stock the aforementioned Cameron autobiography. Never mind that she acknowledges they may just be responding to a lack of demand from readers. ldquoOne bookseller in Hackney declared ndash joking I hope ndash that she wouldnrsquot be making a big deal of it because she could get firebombed... Therersquos something genuinely shocking that bookshops feel that they canrsquot or wonrsquot stock a book by a former prime minister.The only question that should trouble them is is it interesting and is it any good, she says. ldquoOnce bookshops start to no- books we really have lost it.One might hope the courts, with their interest in establishing the truth in the public interest might encourage those columnists seeking moderation. But as constitutional law takes centre-stage, Philip Johnston in theis not so sure. At the Supreme Court the justices are being asked to decide between an executive acting to uphold the will of the people and a Parliament seeking to frustrate it, he says. ldquoIF that is not a political matter then nothing is. The judges should steer well clear, but I am not sure that they will, he says.The TimesDaniel Finkelstein is also looking to the Supreme Court judges to steer a path between ldquofury at the Johnson government... passion against Brexit. Butthe courts are to be involve din politics maybe the public - through parliament - should have a say in appointing them. ldquoTo strike the right balance between the law and politics will not be easy, but at least we are finally beginning to treat the question with the seriousness it deserves.

title: watchdog-demands-say-question-second-referendum
story: The Electoral Commission told MSPs that it needed to test the intelligibility of any question before it was enshrined in legislation and put on the ballot paper.It followed the Scottish Government, through its Referendums Bill at Holyrood, trying to avoid the Commission re-testing any question it had previously approved.In practice, this is aimed at a single instance - the Commissionrsquos approval of the Yes No question ldquoShould Scotland be an independent country  five years ago.Since then, the Commission has ruled against using the same format in case it advantages the Yes side, insisting on a Leave Remain choice for the  EU Referendum.A change to Leave Remain could be tricky for the SNP, which still campaigns for a Yes vote.Last week SNP Brexit secretary Michael Russell told MSPs the  format should be retained for ldquoclarity and consistency and it would be ldquovery confusing to change it.However Dame Sue Bruce, the Electoral Commissioner for Scotland, told the finance committee that any question must be tested.She said: ldquoWe strongly believe that the Commission should be asked to test the question."Putting the voter at the centre of the process, we think a formal testing of the question helps to provide confidence and assurance to the voter and to the Parliament posing the question in terms of the integrity of the process to establish that it is clear and transparent and neutral in its setting."The standard testing procedure would take up to  weeks, with the bulk of the time used for research with the public, including focus groups and in-depth interviews.The Commission would also take advice from experts and undertake a consultation when considering the question, before publishing a report supplied to ministers.Chief executive Bob Posner said the Commission would start with an open mind.He said: ldquoI think its really important to say that we dont start with a preposition at all."The fact that there was in  a referendum in Scotland,we had a repeat of that referendum, it would be a very material consideration that there was a question that was in the publics minds back then and theres a familiarity, and polling since. So all that would be picked up as part of the assessment process but we wouldnt start with any position at all."He added: "No-one should think that just because theres been a  referendum where Remain and Leave was used, there would be any reason why that would be relevant or appropriate for another referendum, or not as the case may be."Head of the Electoral Commission Andy ONeill said allowing it to test the question would mean people would be able to focus on the issues of the debate, rather than discussing the question itself.He said: "We believe context can change, it may not change, we dont know that until weve done the question testing and given you the advice."I think one of the things you get from our expertise is confidence in the question and I think people - the voters, the campaigners - can have confidencewe provide a good product in terms of the advice."You can choose to accept it or not but we give you our advice."That confidence brings acceptance and it brings acceptance from the voter and the campaigners so you can then go off and debate the issues rather than the question."Pamela Nash, chief executive of Scotland in Union, said: ldquoThere shouldnrsquot be another referendum as it would lead to economic turmoil and deeper ision, but -there ever is one - itrsquos vital that itrsquos legal and fair, and doesnrsquot have a rigged question chosen by the SNP.ldquoThe Electoral Commission has said that yes no questions are unfair, and recommended a remain leave question in the EU referendum.ldquoBut this Referendums Bill is taking up parliamentary time that could be better spent on focussing on how to improve public services in Scotland - not ways to create more ision.The Referendums Bill is designed to create a general framework for referendums.However it is aimed primarily at paving the way for Indyref next year,the UK grants Holyrood the required powers for a new vote.

title: uk-holding-back-39-brexit-blueprint-39-focus-eu-minds-run-up-crunch-october-eu-summit
story: The ultimatum came from Antti Rinne, the Finnish Prime Minister, whose country holds the rotating EU presidency, following a meeting with Emmanuel Macron, the French President.In Paris, Mr Rinne expressed his and Mr Macronrsquos concern ldquoabout what is happening in Britain.He told reporters: ldquoWe need to know what the UK is proposing. Loose talk about proposals for negotiations is irresponsiblehellipThe UK should make its possible own proposals very soonthey would like them to be discussed.The Finnish premier then said: ldquoWe both agreed that it is now time for Boris Johnson to produce his own proposals in writingthey exist. If no proposals are received by the end of September, then itrsquos over.Mr Rinnersquos challenge came after UK Government sources suggested Britain was holding back its ldquoBrexit blueprint until after the Conservative Party conference in early October to pile the pressure on Brussels to secure a new deal before the crunch Euro summit on October .Earlier, Jean-Claude Juncker, the outgoing President of the European Commission, complained that no real progress could be made until the UK submitted its formal written proposals.Updating MEPs in Strasbourg, he warned them there remained a "palpable" risk of a no-deal Brexit despite "friendly, constructive and in part positive" talks with Boris Johnson earlier this week."I said to Prime Minister Johnson that I have no emotional attachment to the safety net, to the backstop, but I stated that I stand by the objectives that it is designed to achieve."That is why I called on the Prime Minister to come forward with operational proposals, in writing, for practical steps which would allow us to achieve those objectives."Until such time as those proposals have been presented I will not be able to tell you, looking you straight in the eye, that any real progress has been achieved," declared the EUrsquos top official.But a No  source said: ldquoWe showed them the text of the Northern Ireland protocol without the backstop in it to show them the precision of the removal that wersquore looking for, so they could understand what would still be left.He added: ldquoOnce you share it with  countries, yoursquore not in control of the document. Yoursquove got to be sensible about it.Michel Barnier, the EUrsquos chief negotiator, said the bloc still needed to hear more from the UK side about its proposals for replacing the backstop.He noted: "The new UK Government this week in Luxembourg outlined the aspects of the backstop they dont like. That is not enough, however, to move towards achieving a solution."The UKrsquos Brexit blueprint appears to fall into three categories firstly, an ldquoall-Ireland market for food and agriculture secondly, customs and regulatory checks on other goods undertaken away from the Irish border and, thirdly, a key role for the Stormont Assembly overseeing the new arrangements, once it is back up and running hopefully, during the transition period.Last night, the Prime Minister and Mr Juncker had further talks on the phone with a No  spokesman saying: ldquoThey discussed the positive and constructive conversation they had in Luxembourg on Monday and their shared determination to reach a deal.In further phonecalls, Mr Johnson also discussed matters EU with David Sassoli, the European Parliament President, Nicos Anastasiades, the Cypriot President, and Arturs Karins, the Latvian Prime Minister.ldquoThe Prime Minister updated the other European leaders on the progress of the Brexit talks to date and reiterated that, when the UK leaves the EU on October , his preference is that we do so with a deal. He spoke about the work that was underway to find an alternative to the backstop that protects both the Good Friday Belfast Agreement and the integrity of the single market.Xavier Bettel, the Luxembourg premier, who humiliated the PM earlier this week by mocking him for abandoning a joint press conference because of noisy anti-Brexit protesters, denied it had been a planted ambush, saying he had too much respect for Britain and Mr Johnson to even contemplate such a move.Meanwhile, Michelle OrsquoNeill, Sinn Feins deputy leader, made clear her partyrsquos opposition to a ldquoStormont veto on the Irish backstop because, she argued, a ldquobackstop that can be vetoed is not a backstop".Her remarks came after reports that Northern Irelandrsquos Democratic Unionists might consider endorsing the UK Governmentrsquos contingency plan aimed at preventing a hard borderthe devolved institutions would have a veto on future EU rules applying to the province.Speaking ahead of a speech at the Dublin Chamber of Commerce, Arlene Foster, the DUP leader, stressed how her party wanted a deal that worked for the UK constitutional position."Ive heard from Europe today...about the majority in Northern Ireland wanting to have the backstop. Butyou look at the Belfast Agreement, its about parallel consent its about the consent of Nationalism and the consent of Unionism."There are no Unionist MLAs who support the backstop at present, so therefore there is a need to find a way forward which everybody can buy in to."The DUP leader denied her party was softening its position on Brexit, stressing how it wanted a ldquosensible deal and a sensible way forward.She added: "There is a lot of commentary about the DUP being no-deal Brexiteers but as people look at the evidence they will find something very dferent."

title: comment-donald-martin---scottish-media-never-important
story: In a digital world awash with fake news, deliberate distortion and dishonesty, the Scottish media has never been more important.We deal in the facts, and we strive to meet the highest of professional standards as part of the most regulated press in the free world.But sadly, we face two distinct threats.Firstly that too many people ndash particularly online ndash are quick to undermine the trust and credibility of Scotlandrsquos journalists. As I hope the TV documentary captured, the professionalism and dedication of our industry to provide clarity where there is confusion transparency where there is secrecy truth where there is dishonesty and right where there is wrongdoing, is nothing short of heroic.In newsrooms across the country, journalists work long, long hours day and night to cover the stories that matter to their readers and communities.:Staff still determined their mission matters - TV review, The Papers, BBCYet they do so in the face of an increasingly unforgiving and misinformed audience ndash one where there is a wilful misunderstanding of what journalism is and what journalists do and the prejudices and perceived grievances of the online gallery are carefully orchestrated.It is often dficult to comprehend a society that values freedom and democracy but can so readily dismisses the value and role of a free press.Of course, we get it wrong sometimes. But far, far less often than our critics would have you believe. As is apparent on screen, our journalists care deeply about getting it right.Secondly, the pervasive impact of the tech giants on mainstream media.:Who pays for journalism  As we look to the future, someone will have to provide an answer that worksThe Herald is, of course, an integral and trusted part of Scotlandrsquos media but we are under threat from the unregulated world dominated by internet giants who spend fortunes creating algorithms to plunder our hard-earned journalism and advertising.Regulating online publishers and holding them to the same standards is vital for truth and democracy.As Paul Dacre, former editor of The Daily Mail, says: ldquoThe very le blood of the newspaper industry was being sucked out by an utterly unregulated, defiantly anarchic, arrogantly unaccountable, awesomely ubiquitous digital monster which regarded itself as above the law, churned out fake news, tried to rig elections, invaded citizensrsquo privacy on a cosmic scale, provided succour to terrorists and paedophiles, devastated our high streets, and, oh yes made billions but paid barely any taxes.:Comment - Daily miracle in face of industry changes#Truth and democracy costs and our politicians need to do more to protect the mainstream media at its very heart. Regulating online publishers and holding them to the same standards is vital for truth and democracy.We are not competing on a level playing field.Facebook, Google etc are free to publish what they want unfettered by the requirement to provide accuracy or truth.:Buzzing, sweary and the best place to be#Our journalism is validated, and we are held to account either in law or under the Code of Practice, enforced by the industryrsquos regulator the Independent Press Standards Organisation.But that quality journalism costs and it is a burden we are shouldering whilst our content, revenues and markets are cannibalised by those same tax-avoiding giants.Partnerships where they are helping protect that journalism under threat is one solution, and we need to accelerate and expand current models such as Facebookrsquos community reporters.However, ultimately the future of our industry lies in your hands, dear readers, and I implore you to purchase or subscribe to help us deliver the quality you deserve.

title: boozy-sweary-best-place
story: But the passion to thrive, provide fabulous insight and analysis and get the news out first is as raw and fundamental as it has ever been.The BBCrsquos brilliant new documentary series about le behind the shimmer of steel and glass at The Herald and Times Grouprsquos Renfield Street HQ showed that in all its gory glory.As a former newspaper editor and editor-in-chief myself, I started off watching from behind the sofa expecting a brutal expose of the bad language and dark humour that stalk newsrooms while attempting a fresh attack on journalists as blood-sucking scum with no compassion for their subjects nor passion for their trade.:Donald Martin - the Scottish media has never been more important.What we got instead was a slow-burning and wonderful reportage of the vagaries of le inside the hard-pressed newsrooms of Scotland and beyond.Itrsquos timing was impeccable and offered a triumvirate of challenges that these committed journalists face: the sht from print to digital , the issue of declining resources, and handling some of the biggest stories of the last -or-so years.What the BBC managed to avoid, thankfully, was the cliched view of blood and thunder journalists prepared to be damned infor the best scoop thatrsquos very rarely the case.Here was a beautul illustration of the frustrations of trying to cover some of the most dficult issues of our time against the clock and amid financial and technological pressures. These guys write the thing, do the digital content and then go and produce podcasts to boot ndash the vagaries of being a multi-media hack today.:Staff still determined their mission matters - TV review, The Papers, BBCThe old war horses Richard Walker and Donald Martin prowled the joined-up newsroom as the titles vied for the best line on that dayrsquos Brexit balls-up and the chance to win the digital and circulation war at least for one day.Donaldrsquos stoicism in the face of mounting management challenges was impressive and Richardrsquos foul languagejust poetic. I know they must have cut far more out.The star of the show was young blood Callum Baird who showed his Brexit balls by stfing Theresa May when she locked The National out of a press conference.The editor did his bit by refusing to cover the story and leaving the front page blank ndash something wersquove all wanted to do, but very few have the chutzpah to do it. Callum and his crew offered a bright light for the future.:Who pays for journalism  As we look to the future, someone will have to provide an answer that works#The issues are clear, however the challenges stark and the increasing pressures on people dedicated to their craft are more intense. As a consultant on reputation management, I understand why some may see it as brave to let the cameras roll, where the editing process is out of your hands.However from a brand perspective it delivers clear positive messages about the teamrsquos commitment to quality, and offers a cracking insight and engagement for readers and a potential new audience.By showing it as it is rather than stage managing the presentation it has an engaging authenticity that underpins the value of trusted journalism.It also revealed why there is no better place to be when a big story is breaking than in the heart of a buzzing, sweary, time-constrained and under-resourced newsroom. Ironically for TV, this series is going to be a cracker of a page-turner.*Damian Bates is a former newspaper editor and editor-in-chief and is now a media and reputation management consultant, company chairman and author of a book on Donald Trump.

title: comment---daily-miracle-face-industry-changes
story: The chance to get a message across, to let the public see what really goes on behind the scenes, is a seductive offer and so it is with the first of BBC Scotlandrsquos two-parter The Papers, in which this fine publication and its sisters opened their doors to the cameras, aired last night.Even from the advance clips the message is clear. That to deliver a big daily newspaper with a -year tradition of excellence and enormous reader expectations was always a massive job, but with unprecedented assaults on its financial stability from the technology giants, it is a daily miracle.: Donald Martin - the Scottish media has never been more important.It is exactly the same story at my old stable, Scotsman Publications. When I edited the Edinburgh Evening News at the turn of the century I had a staff of , with  at The Scotsman and  at Scotland on Sunday, plus healthy freelance budgets. Now a complement of just  get all their titles over the door.The advance of businesses like Craigrsquos List, Gumtree and Ebay attacked classied markets for jobs, motors and property, then Google and Facebook savaged the display advertising markets. The most serious effects have happened in the space of  years, leaving publishers with huge wage bills no choice but to slash costs and increase prices to compensate.:Boozy, sweary and the best place to be#While the printed papers themselves might be smaller, the reality is that the number of products and services themselves have expanded. It is an exhausting environment, but the industryrsquos record of experiment, innovation and audience growth under extreme pressure is remarkable.But for revenue there were only ever two real options: generate a big enough digital audience through free access to generate advertising revenue or start charging for digital access through paywalls. It has become clear that the audiences required to make money from free access are vast ndash Mail Online has only started to generate a profit, but it has taken huge amounts of money and an enormous staff to generate over m daily users to make that possible, resources beyond most publishers.:TV review, The Papers, BBCAnd in a UK context, the other option of establishing paywall systems runs into the constant problem that the BBC does a fine job in providing a broad, free-to-access service which all but political extremists regard as excellent. Why pay for a Herald, Scotsman or Times subscription when the BBC is available at the dab of an app for free  Except of course it isnrsquot free. You pay through your licence fee, just as you pay for the NHS though your taxes, but it has given the BBC a virtual blank cheque compared to other news operators. The irony that it has taken a BBC documentary to take this message to a wider audience is not on the business.But the BBC faces its own crisis, and while it is busy spending poundm a year launching a new linear, terrestrial BBC Scotland channel, new audiences are streaming services like Netflix and will never see the need to buy a licence. The BBC is increasingly just another hunter in a digital jungle.Fast-moving overseas tech companies unburdened by legacy costs but who use and abuse audience data are the real enemy of properly researched, checked and curated news services, but feed off them without putting a penny back, apart from token projects to buy-off threatening legislation. Over % of people in the UK read a mainstream independent news publication at least once a month ndash The Herald alone now has two million monthly users and reaches thousand more people than in the s hey-day ndash so itrsquos not an audience problem they face but a revenue one.:Who pays for journalism  As we look to the future, someone will have to provide an answer that works#The Cairncross and Furman reports about the future of news and digital competition present solutions which are now sitting with the UK Government, but it will take political will to change the media and news landscape while minds are on other matters. Itrsquos about time they were grasped before itrsquos too late.John McLellan is Director of the Scottish Newspaper Society

title: david-cameron-secretly-39-begged-39-queen-back-union-2014-scottish-independence-campaign
story: The former Prime Minister made the highly unconstitutional move ndash to involve the head of state in a political campaign - while staying at Balmoral Castle during a tense weekend when a poll put the Yes campaign ahead for the first time.In a BBC documentary about his time in office, Mr Cameron admitted the snapshot in a Sunday newspaper just  days before the historic vote was ldquolike a blow to the solar plexus and led to a ldquomounting sense of panic that this could go the wrong way.He tells the programme: ldquoI remember conversations I had with my Private Secretary and he had with the Queenrsquos Private Secretary and I had with the Queenrsquos Private Secretary, not asking for anything that would be in any way improper or unconstitutional but just a raising of the eyebrow even you know, a quarter of an inch, we thought would make a dference.: lsquoMother of parliaments closed by the father of liesrsquo court toldA few days later, the Queen famously told a well-wisher outside nearby Craithie Kirk that she hoped ldquopeople would think very carefully about the future regarded at the time and since as Her Majesty urging Scots to stick with the Union.In an interview at the weekend about his autobiography, For The Record, Mr Cameron said how he had been ldquodelighted by the Queenrsquos intervention.He tells the BBC documentary: ldquoIt was certainly well covered [by the media], although the words were very limited. It helped to put a slightly dferent perception on things.Shortly after the referendum result on September  , the ex-PM was caught on a TV camera during a visit to New York, telling Michael Bloomberg, the then cityrsquos mayor, how Her Majesty had ldquopurred down the line when he informed of the referendum result.Mr Cameron later apologised to the Queen, admitting he had felt ldquoextremely sorry and very embarrassed for confirming she had wanted Scotland to remain in the UK.Todayrsquos bombshell revelation comes in the week that marks the fth anniversary of the referendum result - when Scots backed maintaining the -year-old Union by  per cent to  per cent - and when the UK Supreme Court deliberates on whether Prime Minister Boris Johnsonrsquos decision to suspend Parliament for five weeks was lawful and which many politicians protested had dragged the Queen into politics.Last night, Alex Salmond, the former First Minister, said: ldquoBegging a constitutional monarch to make a political intervention is not only totally improper but an indication of how desperate Prime Minister Cameron was in the final stages of the Scottish referendum campaign.ldquoScotland should always remember that Westminster does not recognise any political rule book, declared the ex-party leader.He added: ldquoCameron started the campaign uber-confident and ended up in a blue funk. I doubt If Scotland will let the Establishment off the hook next time around.The SNP declined to comment but a senior source said: ldquoWe have tried not to drag the Queen into political things others may or may not do.A spokeswoman for the Queen told The Herald: ldquoItrsquos not something we are commenting on at all.Mr Cameronrsquos highly controversial admission does not appear in tonightrsquos first instalment of The Cameron Years on BBC  at pm, "A Huge Fight on My Hands," but in the second part of the programme, ldquoThe Best is Yet to Come, broadcast next week.In his memoirs, For The Record, Mr Cameron recalled the tense run-in to the independence vote and his stay at Balmoral when at a hillside barbecue members of the Royal Family ldquogingerly asked questions but knew they shouldnrsquot express too strong an opinion.The next morning, conversation turned to the opinion poll. ldquoI tried to reassure them about lsquorogue pollsrsquo but I was struggling to convince myself, let alone them, wrote the former PM.Mr Cameron, whose late father Ian was from Aberdeenshire, made clear that he would not have resignedhe had been the prime minister to lose the -year-old Union but noted how he felt ldquo I were the one who precipitated the end of our island story, it would hurt beyond belief.: Johnson given two-week deadline to produce UKs backstop alternative or "its over," warns EU leaderIn tonightrsquos programme, George Osborne, the former Chancellor, reveals the depth of his opposition to Mr Cameron calling another referendum on Britainrsquos membership of the EU.He says he is ldquovery sorry for what happened and admits he feels ldquoresponsible because of his role at the Treasury, adding that ldquowe held a referendum we should never have held and the ldquoconsequences for the country are grave.He openly criticises the former PMrsquos approach saying: ldquoDavid Cameron was just one of a number of British Prime Ministers who had fed this idea that we were dferent than Europe, that Brussels was to blame and that the public ultimately had to have a say, and wersquove all paid a price for it.Mr Osborne, now the editor of the London Evening Standard, points out the ldquoonly thing I can plea in my mitigation ishellipI made the case against it but it wasnrsquot heard.Mr Cameron and his then Chancellor also speak openly about the fraught conversations they had in the Downing St flat, trying to convince their then friend and colleague Michael Gove to come down on their side for Remain.The Cabinet Office Minister, who became a leading figure in the Leave campaign, explains how he felt ldquosome of the conversations we had were attempts on his part[Mr Cameronrsquos] to reassure himself that our friendship would mean that I wouldnrsquot stray from the fold.The Scot goes on: ldquoDavid understandably felt that since Irsquod been prepared to knuckle under on a number of occasions beforehand and put my own feelings to one side in order to serve the team, that on this occasion, that I would do the same.Mr Cameron, who has branded Mr Gove a disloyal liar, describes as a ldquobombshell the moment when he confirmed that he would support the Leave campaign.Mr Osborne recalls the moment he warned his former Cabinet colleague, telling him: ldquoIf you go to the Leave campaign, you will destroy this Governmentwe lose this title: call for shops to close on new year s day
story: The shopworkers# trade union is urging all MSPs to back a motion calling for the closure of large shops in New Year#s Day.A survey of Scottish retail staff by the union Usdaw shows overwhelming support for the closure of stores on January .And the union is now calling on all MSPs to support the motion tabled by Jackie Baillie MSP in the Scottish Parliament seeking to ensure shop workers can enjoy some time off at New Year.The survey of more than  shop workers revealed:•  per cent believed stores should close on New Year’s Day, with  per cent saying they should also close on January .• Three quarters feel they spend too little time with friends and family over New Year.•  per cent have come under pressure to work on New Year’s Day or January .• Four in ten don’t receive any premium pay for working on New Year’s Day.•  per cent are not happy to work on New Year’s Day or January .Stewart Forrest, Usdaw’s Scottish isional officer, said: “This survey clearly demonstrates the strength feeling among our members. “We have written to all MSPs asking them to support Jackie Baillie’s motion calling for a decent break at New Year after the busy Christmas period.“I have also written to the Scottish Retail Consortium urging them to reconsider their opposition to large stores closing on New Year’s Day.”Mr Forrest stressed the union was fully supportive of efforts to revitalise our high streets as the livelihoods of its members depended on a thriving retail sector.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.kirkintilloch-herald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Failing to get young pets vaccinated leaves them exposed to fatal diseases." title: garioch sports centre serves up an ace with new tennis plans
story: With the nation currently hooked on Wimbledon, it#s a fitting time for Garioch Sports Centre to unveil its new tennis-focused proposals.Inverurie Community Council has submitted fresh expansion plans to Aberdeenshire Council on behalf of Garioch Sports Holdings.Full planning permission was secured last year for a major extension of the Inverurie facility, but changes in the community’s requirements and pressures on funding have prompted a reduced development.Initially the plans would have seen the Burghmuir Drive centre expanding into one of the largest amenities of its kind in Scotland, incorporating tennis courts, a multi-sports arena, fitness suites and an all-weather G pitch for Inverurie Loco Works FC which has now been dropped.But while the scale of the expansion might not be as ambitious, the new plans do reveal tennis courts and improvements for fitness along with an Early Learning Centre for younger children.Thanks to signicant input from Judy Murray – mother of tennis stars Andy and Jamie – the plans feature three dedicated tennis courts and the centre has committed to a three-year partnership with the JM Foundation, highlighting the commitment of the centre to develop the sport across Garioch.The centre and JM Foundation will work in partnership in upskilling their workforce and identying potential coaches while funding coach education.In a supporting statement the centre writes: “The matter of securing the appropriate funding for the ious options which have been considered over the last couple of years has impacted upon how the plans have altered with the focus very much now being on the new tennis provision.“The most recent plans reflect the discussions with the Lawn Tennis Association and also Tennis Scotland.“The advice and guidance of Judy Murray has also been pivotal in how the plans particularly for the tennis courts have progressed.”The applicants also believe that despite the downturn in oil and gas and other industries, there is still a demand for its facilities.It reports: “As many of the activities and programmes now carry waiting lists, there is proof that despite a downturn in many industries the timing is now right to expand in tandem with the growth in participation and the increase in the town and rural residency.“An expansion of the present facility and delivery of its sporting, health and wellbeing activities has many positive additions as the market town itself strives to increase its provision to its residents.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill title: prime minister announces extra funding for scots farmers
story: Scotland#s farming leaders have welcomed #. million of extra funding announced by the Prime Minister on a visit to Aberdeenshire.The cash, over the next two years, is in addition to the £ million package for farmers unveiled earlier this week as part of the Government’s Spending Review.Boris Johnson announced the additional money, recommended in the Bew Review, during a visit to a farm near Banchory where he met NFU Scotland officials.He’d earlier toured Peterhead fishmarket.Speaking after meeting Mr Johnson, NFU Scotland president Andrew McCornick said: “On top of the Chancellor’s welcome announcement in his spending review that Scotland is to receive £ million in convergence funding, we welcome the positive outcome of the Bew Review into future funding allocations and Government’s speedy response to the review’s recommendations.“Taken together, the two announcements will inject £ million into Scottish agriculture over the next two years. At a time of uncertainty, that represents the largest funding uplt for the sector in recent memory.”The Prime Minister is expected to stay overnight at Balmoral before ing south tomorrow. data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The taskforce will examine the causes of drug-related deaths, and seek solutions to prevent the use of drugs resulting in the loss of so many lives." title: a waste of money oic homes in on refuse issues
story: Should Orkney deal with its own rubbish rather than paying hundreds of thousands of pounds annually to ship it where That was the question on the lips of several councillors on Tuesday, as they faced a £, overspend in Orkney Islands Council#s waste disposal budget.With the council spending a total of £,, on dumping refuse in the past year, on top of £, to collect it, members of the OIC development and infrastructure committee are keen to find a solution — either by lobbying the Scottish Government for more funding, or by investing in a method of dealing with waste in-house.#We need to find a local solution,# said Kirkwall West and Orphir councillor Leslie Manson, who pointed out that the shipping of waste also contradicted anti-climate change policies.#If we cannot deal with refuse, we have to use lots of fossil fuel to get it where.#He later added: #We have to pay money to ship it where it gets buried for a while. We need to deal with our waste responsibility at home.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ
